Problem:
Consider an electrical circuit with a constant voltage source V and a linear resistor R in series with a capacitor C. The charge Q on the capacitor is governed by the differential equation \\(\\frac{dQ}{dt} = \\frac{V - Q/C}{R}\\). We study the impact of applying a sinusoidal function \\(f(t) = A \\sin(\\omega t)\\) as an external forcing term to the circuit.

If the function \\(f(t)\\) is applied to the circuit at t = 0 and the system is allowed to evolve without further intervention, will \\(Q(t)\\) at t = T be the same as if no external forcing term was applied?
Explanation: The introduction of the external forcing term \\(f(t) = A \\sin(\\omega t)\\) modifies the differential equation governing the charge Q. This results in a different solution for Q(t), potentially causing oscillatory behavior that would not occur without the forcing term.
